meanings.def: to own, hold or possess something
examples: He had a new car and a boat.
Have you got a job yet?
I don't have that much money on me.
She's got a BA in English.
They’ve got a wonderful house.
We haven’t got a television.
Have you got a meeting today?
Do you have any brothers and sisters?
We don’t have a car
I have no objection to your request.
Have you an appointment?
I’m sorry, I haven’t a clue.
They had a wonderful house.
We didn’t have much time.
Did she have her husband with her?
They have a wonderful house.
We don’t have a television.
Do you have a meeting today?
‘Does your brother have brown hair?’ ‘No, he’s got blond hair.’
We don’t often have time to talk.

meanings.def: be made up of
examples: In 2018 the party had 10 000 members.

meanings.def: to show a quality or feature
examples: have something The ham had a smoky flavour.
The house has gas-fired central heating.
The car has four-wheel drive.
They have a lot of courage.
have something + adj. He's got a front tooth missing.

meanings.def: to show a particular quality by your actions
examples: Surely she didn't have the nerve to say that to him?

meanings.def: used to show a particular relationship
examples: He's got three children.
Do you have a client named Peters?

meanings.def: to be able to make use of something because it is available
examples: Have you got time to call him?
We have no choice in the matter.

meanings.def: to be in a position where you ought to do something
examples: We have a duty to care for the refugees.

meanings.def: to be in a position of needing to do something
examples: have something I've got a lot of homework tonight.
have something to do I must go—I have a bus to catch.

meanings.def: to let a feeling or thought come into your mind
examples: He had the strong impression that someone was watching him.
We've got a few ideas for the title.
(informal) I've got it! We'll call it ‘Word Magic’.

meanings.def: to suffer from an illness or a disease
examples: I've got a headache.
He found out that he had HIV just last year.
I had a cold yesterday and I couldn't come to work.

meanings.def: to hold somebody/something in the way mentioned
examples: She'd got him by the collar.
He had his head in his hands.

meanings.def: to place or keep something in a particular position
examples: Mary had her back to me.
I soon had the fish in a net.

meanings.def: to experience something
examples: I went to a few parties and had a good time.
I was having difficulty in staying awake.
She'll have an accident one day.

meanings.def: to organize or hold an event
examples: Let's have a party.

meanings.def: to eat, drink or smoke something
examples: to have breakfast/lunch/dinner
I'll have the salmon (= for example, in a restaurant).
I had a coffee while I was waiting.
Have you had breakfast yet?
I just had a sandwich for lunch.
He went outside to have a cigarette.

meanings.def: to perform a particular action
examples: I had a swim to cool down.
(British English) to have a wash/shower/bath
We had a very interesting discussion about climate change.

meanings.def: to give birth to somebody/something
examples: She's going to have a baby.
Our cat has just had five kittens.

meanings.def: to produce a particular effect
examples: His paintings had a strong influence on me as a student.
The colour green has a restful effect.

meanings.def: to receive something from somebody
examples: I had a letter from my brother this morning.
Can I have a Coke, please?

meanings.def: to be given something; to have something done to you
examples: I'm having treatment for my back problem.
How many driving lessons have you had so far?

meanings.def: to experience the effects of somebody’s actions
examples: We have orders coming in from all over the world.

meanings.def: to suffer the effects of what somebody else does to you
examples: She had her bag stolen.

meanings.def: to cause something to be done for you by somebody else
examples: You've had your hair cut!
We're having our car repaired.

meanings.def: to tell or arrange for somebody to do something for you
examples: have somebody do something He had the bouncers throw them out of the club.
(informal) I'll have you know (= I'm telling you) I'm a black belt in judo.
have somebody + adv./prep. She's always having the builders in to do something or other.

meanings.def: to cause somebody/something to be in a particular state; to make somebody react in a particular way
examples: have somebody/something + adj. I want to have everything ready in good time.
have somebody/something doing something He had his audience listening attentively.

meanings.def: to be with somebody
examples: She had some friends with her.

meanings.def: to take care of somebody/something in your home, especially for a limited period
examples: We're having the kids for the weekend.

meanings.def: to entertain somebody in your home
examples: We had some friends to dinner last night.

meanings.def: to allow something; to accept something without complaining
examples: have something I'm sick of your rudeness—I won't have it any longer!
have somebody/something doing something We can't have people arriving late all the time.

meanings.def: to put somebody at a disadvantage in an argument
examples: You've got me there. I hadn't thought of that.

meanings.def: to have sex with somebody
examples: He had her in his office.

meanings.def: to trick or cheat somebody
examples: be had I'm afraid you've been had.

meanings.def: to take or accept somebody for a particular role
examples: Who can we have as treasurer?

meanings.def: to dislike somebody because of something bad they have done to you in the past
examples: I don’t have anything against her, we just don’t get along.

meanings.def: to finish something unpleasant so that it does not continue
examples: Let's have done with this silly argument.

meanings.def: to be in a very bad condition; to be unable to be repaired
examples: The car had had it.

meanings.def: to be extremely tired
examples: I've had it! I'm going to bed.

meanings.def: to have lost all chance of surviving something
examples: When the truck smashed into me, I thought I'd had it.

meanings.def: to be going to experience something unpleasant
examples: Dad saw you scratch the car—you've had it now!

meanings.def: to be unable to accept a situation any longer
examples: I’ve had it (up to here) with him—he’s done it once too often.

meanings.def: to claim that it is a fact that…
examples: Rumour has it that we'll have a new manager soon.

meanings.def: to be likely to suffer the unpleasant effects of your actions and to deserve to do so
examples: It was no surprise when she left him—everyone knew he had it coming to him.

meanings.def: to not like somebody and be unpleasant to them
to be capable of doing something
examples: Everyone thinks he has it in him to produce a literary classic.
You were great. I didn't know you had it in you.
You spoke really well at that meeting, standing up for us all. I never knew you had it in you.

meanings.def: to have sex with somebody
to be not nearly as good as somebody/something
not willing to listen to or believe something
examples: I tried to persuade her to wait but she wasn't having any.

meanings.def: other things, people, etc. of the same kind
examples: There's room in the cellar to store old furniture and what have you.

idioms.def: to dislike somebody because of something bad they have done to you in the past
examples: I don’t have anything against her, we just don’t get along.

idioms.def: to finish something unpleasant so that it does not continue
examples: Let's have done with this silly argument.

idioms.def: to be in a very bad condition; to be unable to be repaired
examples: The car had had it.
I've had it! I'm going to bed.
When the truck smashed into me, I thought I'd had it.
Dad saw you scratch the car—you've had it now!
I’ve had it (up to here) with him—he’s done it once too often.

idioms.def: to claim that it is a fact that…
examples: Rumour has it that we'll have a new manager soon.

idioms.def: to be likely to suffer the unpleasant effects of your actions and to deserve to do so
examples: It was no surprise when she left him—everyone knew he had it coming to him.

idioms.def: to not like somebody and be unpleasant to them

idioms.idiom: have it in you (to do something)
idioms.def: to be capable of doing something
examples: Everyone thinks he has it in him to produce a literary classic.
You were great. I didn't know you had it in you.
You spoke really well at that meeting, standing up for us all. I never knew you had it in you.

idioms.def: to be not nearly as good as somebody/something
not willing to listen to or believe something
examples: I tried to persuade her to wait but she wasn't having any.

idioms.def: other things, people, etc. of the same kind
examples: There's room in the cellar to store old furniture and what have you.

related: Pussy Cat, Pussy Cat, Where Have You Been?
have a dog in the race/hunt

meanings.def: used with the past participle to form perfect tenses
examples: I've finished my work.
He's gone home, hasn't he?
‘Have you seen it?’ ‘Yes, I have/No, I haven’t.’
She'll have had the results by now.
Had they left before you got there?
If I hadn't seen it with my own eyes I wouldn't have believed it.
(formal) Had I known that (= if I had known that) I would never have come.
I could of told you that.
I could've told you that.
